quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But another really important asset to the world is our code, our open source.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Reframes open-source code as a globally valuable asset worth preserving and investing in, not just a byproduct of software development.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This represents actually a lot of the collective, well, certainly software, if not intelligence of kind of the modern world, right?
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model: public code as a repository of collective intelligence, which helps justify using it as foundational training data.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We had put this snapshot of public repositories on this silver film that would be preserved for thousands of years in this Arctic Code Vault.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A concrete example of treating code preservation as long-term infrastructure, illustrating how a single dataset can serve multiple strategic purposes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Well, we took that same data snapshot and we brought it to our friends over at OpenAI to see like, okay, what can we do with these large language models built on public code?
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: repurpose existing high-quality datasets and partner with specialized teams to explore new product capabilities quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I'm always really curious how a big product like this starts, gets buy in, build momentum, and then launches, especially at a big company like Microsoft and especially a product like Copilot that has surprising ethics challenges, scaling challenges, business model questions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product-development checklist for AI products in large orgs: buy-in, momentum, launch, plus ethics, scaling, and business model risks.

quotes.topic_title: Host intro: Copilot, stakes, and questions
quotes.text: I'm always really curious how a big product like this starts, gets buy in, build momentum, and then launches, especially at a big company like Microsoft and especially a product like Copilot that has surprising ethics challenges, scaling challenges, business model questions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames a practical checklist of hurdles (buy-in, momentum, launch, ethics, scaling, business model) to proactively plan for when shipping AI products inside large organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Host intro: Copilot, stakes, and questions
quotes.text: Also, this came out of a small R&D team that GitHub has, and it's so interesting to hear what Ryan has learned about incubating big bets within a large company, and then taking them from prototype to Microsoft scale.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable innovation path: incubate big bets in a small R&D team, then scale from prototype to enterprise-level rollout.

quotes.topic_title: Host intro: Copilot, stakes, and questions
quotes.text: If you haven't heard of it, it uses OpenAI's machine learning engine to autocomplete code for engineers in real time as they're coding.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a concrete product mechanism (real-time code autocomplete powered by OpenAI) that practitioners can use as a reference point for AI-assisted workflow design.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But primarily it was really about how do we, as people, communicate with each other, how do we express ourselves through creativity.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Reframes product/engineering work as fundamentally about human communication and creative expression—useful as a guiding lens for building tools and experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We're at a really, really unique time in human history where we actually get to witness the advent of a brand new medium.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A mental model for motivation and strategy: treat software as an emergent creative medium, which can change how you prioritize innovation and craft.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When the acquisition happened, it was clear that so much of the energy, so much of the focus and the innovation that was going to be happening around developer tools and services was going to be happening around GitHub.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Actionable career/strategy heuristic: follow where the “energy” and innovation are concentrating, especially after major ecosystem shifts like acquisitions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Like I said, I'm motivated. What I care about is helping people create. It was very clear to me that there was no place that I could have a larger impact than working at GitHub.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A practical decision rule for role selection: optimize for leverage/impact aligned to your core motivation (here, enabling creation).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The decision to move as well, I think, was really focused not just on what GitHub was and maybe is at the time, but what GitHub also can be.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A scalable evaluation framework: assess opportunities based on future potential (“can be”), not only current-state reality.

quotes.topic_title: Ryan’s education and path into product
quotes.text: But primarily it was really about how do we, as people, communicate with each other, how do we express ourselves through creativity.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Frames product/engineering as fundamentally about human communication and creative expression—a useful lens for building user-centered products.

quotes.topic_title: Ryan’s education and path into product
quotes.text: I was just really interested in how we convey our experience of the world to others.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the core job of product: translating human experience into something others can understand and use.

quotes.topic_title: Ryan’s education and path into product
quotes.text: I got started in software development and product management because I wanted to be in the business of creativity.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Repositions product management as enabling creativity, which can guide teams toward tools and workflows that empower users rather than just optimize metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Ryan’s education and path into product
quotes.text: We're at a really, really unique time in human history where we actually get to witness the advent of a brand new medium.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A mental model for practitioners: treat software (and by extension AI) as an emerging creative medium, encouraging experimentation and new interaction paradigms.

quotes.topic_title: Ryan’s education and path into product
quotes.text: That's what I've been doing for the last about a little bit more than 20 years now, working sometimes in startups, some of them other people, some of them my own, about 10 years at Microsoft and now three years at GitHub.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Concrete career data point showing a long, varied path across startups and big tech—useful for understanding how product leaders build breadth over time.

quotes.topic_title: Transition from Microsoft to GitHub
quotes.text: When the acquisition happened, it was clear that so much of the energy, so much of the focus and the innovation that was going to be happening around developer tools and services was going to be happening around GitHub. I mean, that's where the community is creating.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for career/product bets: follow where the community’s creation energy and innovation are concentrating.

quotes.topic_title: Transition from Microsoft to GitHub
quotes.text: What I care about is helping people create. It was very clear to me that there was no place that I could have a larger impact than working at GitHub.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A values-to-decision filter for choosing roles/products: optimize for maximum impact aligned to what you care about most.

quotes.topic_title: Transition from Microsoft to GitHub
quotes.text: That was what I wanted to accomplish, is just like, how do I get more connected to the community, especially the community outside of what Microsoft could reach on its own.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Highlights the leverage of building closer to broad, external communities rather than only internal/enterprise audiences.

quotes.topic_title: Transition from Microsoft to GitHub
quotes.text: And to get to an opportunity to work on so many V1 products, like that is creation itself, to be able to build an entirely new product, get it out to market, test it, iterate on it, and really feed on the energy that's coming back from the community.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A clear V1 product-building loop: ship, test in-market, iterate, and use community feedback as the energy source.

quotes.topic_title: What GitHub Copilot is and why it matters
quotes.text: Copilot is essentially that magnified by many lines of code. It is multi-line autocomplete that is fundamentally powered by an AI model called CodeX, which is a derivative of another one that you might be familiar with, GPT-3.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for positioning Copilot: not “AI coding,” but autocomplete scaled from tokens to multi-line code generation.

quotes.topic_title: What GitHub Copilot is and why it matters
quotes.text: Based upon the variables around it, the class names, the method names around it, your comments, Copilot infers what you intend to create, and then hopefully does a pretty good job at nailing it by providing scaffolding code template that you can then riff on.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how to get better outputs: provide rich local context (names, surrounding code, comments) so the model can infer intent and generate useful scaffolding.

quotes.topic_title: What GitHub Copilot is and why it matters
quotes.text: The labor of remembering what's the order of parameters that need to come into a particular API, or hey, what's the particular syntax of this thing I'm supposed to do, or oh, I've got to create a bunch of dummy data that is days of the week or months in the year. That's just labor. It's not creating. It's just typing.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that separates “creating” from “typing,” clarifying where AI assistance can remove low-value work without replacing core product thinking.

quotes.topic_title: What GitHub Copilot is and why it matters
quotes.text: Copilot helps developers stay in the flow by bringing all of that information into the editor, preventing them from having to go check out documentation or watch tutorial or go to Stack Overflow and either find an answer or worse, have to ask a question and wait for an answer.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A practical productivity principle: reduce context switching by embedding answers directly in the primary workflow (the editor) to preserve developer flow.

quotes.topic_title: What GitHub Copilot is and why it matters
quotes.text: I was watching some YouTube videos to prepare for this chat and one guy, maybe this is the Turing Test of AI writing code, is he used Copilot to center divs. He's like, "Wow! This did it right."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of Copilot’s perceived “magic” in solving a notoriously fiddly, real-world task (CSS centering).

quotes.topic_title: Notable Copilot use cases and learning benefits
quotes.text: His experience matches my own, which is that many of us, we learn to code best not by arbitrary exercises, but by actually building something that's going to be useful solving problems.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A practical learning model: prioritize real, useful projects over contrived exercises to accelerate skill acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Notable Copilot use cases and learning benefits
quotes.text: What he does is he matches small businesses and medium size businesses who need to build internal tools with essentially classes of students, like a group of maybe six or eight students, and then gives those students Copilot and says, "Here, small business, medium size business. Group of students, go build this internal tool for this business."
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable program design for experiential learning: pair real business needs with small student teams and AI assistance.

quotes.topic_title: Notable Copilot use cases and learning benefits
quotes.text: Copilot is essentially kind of whispering in the student's ear, metaphorically speaking, "Hey, here's how you solve this problem. Here's how you do this," and students build not only the tool, the software that the business needs and then get to put that on their resume and their application for college and university, but they also get to learn by using the tools that likely are going to be part of the core DNA of the developer tool chain two, three, four years from now, as AI starts to permeate our entire stack.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Shows a dual-benefit approach: deliver real business value while training students on the emerging AI-native developer workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Notable Copilot use cases and learning benefits
quotes.text: One of the really magical pieces of Copilot here is that, that AI is collecting context of the application that you're going into. It can help you build that mental map and learn the code base, even if it's a language that you're already familiar with.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A transferable mental model: use AI to rapidly build a “mental map” of unfamiliar codebases, not just to generate code.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: OpenAI data, Arctic snapshot, UX choices
quotes.text: Couple years ago now, it kind of dawned on us that, well, language models aren't just English and Spanish and German and Korean and Japanese, but Python and JavaScript and Java and C# and Closure.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A reframing that expands the mental model of “language” to include programming languages—opening up new product opportunities for LLMs.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: OpenAI data, Arctic snapshot, UX choices
quotes.text: In fact, they're kind of nice from an AI perspective because they're relatively constrained in terms of their semantics, right?
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: domains with tighter semantics (like code) can be especially well-suited for early LLM productization.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: OpenAI data, Arctic snapshot, UX choices
quotes.text: We noticed one day that we were getting hammered, I mean absolutely hammered with a tremendous amount of clone requests.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A concrete example of how model/data experimentation can create real operational load—and why infra teams must be involved early.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: OpenAI data, Arctic snapshot, UX choices
quotes.text: Let's see if we can get that data to you in a more responsible way, in a way that's packaged a little bit more to meet your needs.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Actionable partnership lesson: when demand creates strain, shift from ad-hoc scraping to a deliberate, well-packaged data pipeline.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: OpenAI data, Arctic snapshot, UX choices
quotes.text: That was nice because it would give you hold functions, but it's out of the cursor, right?
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A UX principle for developer tools: keep AI assistance in-flow (at the cursor) to reduce context switching and distraction.

quotes.topic_title: Model tuning, latency targets, and prompt crafting
quotes.text: Creating the model is one thing, but then figuring out how to use the model in terms of what parameters do you want to adjust for, what do you want to optimize for in terms of... A great example of this is performance, right?
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Highlights the productization mindset: model quality alone isn’t enough—you must choose explicit optimization targets like performance.

quotes.topic_title: Model tuning, latency targets, and prompt crafting
quotes.text: When you're in a code editor, you don't necessarily want to type, type, type and then have to wait one second, two seconds, three seconds to get a suggestion back when your entire goal is to stay in the flow.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Actionable UX principle for AI features: latency directly impacts user flow, so response time is a core product requirement.

quotes.topic_title: Model tuning, latency targets, and prompt crafting
quotes.text: We would run experiments to see how many milliseconds are the right amount such that a developer doesn't feel like they're being interrupted by Copilot and a suggestion.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Suggests a methodology: empirically test latency thresholds against perceived interruption rather than guessing.

quotes.topic_title: Model tuning, latency targets, and prompt crafting
quotes.text: It seems like right now it's around 200 milliseconds. Depending upon where you're in the world, your latency can go up or down a little bit from there. But it seems like the sweet spot is somewhere around 200 milliseconds.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Provides a concrete performance target practitioners can use as a benchmark for “in-flow” AI assistance.

quotes.topic_title: Model tuning, latency targets, and prompt crafting
quotes.text: We also experimented quite a bit. It's not just about the model, but it's also about what you feed the model. How do you prompt the model to return back a useful response? This kind of began a journey of experimentation for what we call prompt crafting.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Emphasizes that prompt design is a key lever in product quality and should be treated as an experimentation discipline.

quotes.topic_title: GitHub Next, horizons framework, and incubation model
quotes.text: But we generally think of it more as a measure of ambiguity and confidence level more than calendar dates.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Reframes the “three horizons” model as uncertainty-driven (ambiguity/confidence) rather than time-driven, which changes how teams should staff and evaluate bets.

quotes.topic_title: GitHub Next, horizons framework, and incubation model
quotes.text: where we've actually ring-fenced a team to think about that horizon two and horizon three work and kept them separate from EPD.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A concrete organizational design tactic: isolate horizon 2/3 exploration from core execution teams to protect different operating constraints.

quotes.topic_title: GitHub Next, horizons framework, and incubation model
quotes.text: Don't expect anything out of them that is going to turn into a money maker or something that is going to be beholden to fundamentals around security, privacy, uptime, accessibility, all that groovy kind of stuff upfront. They need space to create and experiment.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance for incubation teams: delay production-grade constraints and monetization expectations to maximize creative exploration.

quotes.topic_title: GitHub Next, horizons framework, and incubation model
quotes.text: when you do get to a place where that team has an idea that is clearly connected to a representative set of customers who have a genuine problem and there is signal with at least medium confidence that this solution, whatever it is, solves it in a novel way, that's the time to start thinking about, okay, let's actually put a little bit of... I'm going to call this market testing.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Defines a practical trigger for shifting from research to validation: real customer problem + representative signal + medium confidence, then broaden prototype exposure.

quotes.topic_title: GitHub Next, horizons framework, and incubation model
quotes.text: But it was that moment when we identified that, okay, this is actually something real. Customers are saying, developers are saying, "This is magical. This does something extraordinary that I could not do on my own," that we started to think about, okay, how do we transition this over?
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Shows the specific adoption signal (“this is magical… I could not do on my own”) that prompted the handoff from incubation (Next) to productization (EPD).

quotes.topic_title: Hand-off from research to product teams
quotes.text: We made an intentional decision to take some of the researchers who were in the Next team and for a finite period of time, move them over to create a new EPD squad.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A concrete handoff mechanism: temporarily embed researchers into a product squad to seed knowledge transfer and productization.

quotes.topic_title: Hand-off from research to product teams
quotes.text: The criteria for moving researchers back into their R&D team, whatever that happens to be for your organization, that can't be based on a calendar. It needs to be based on a replacement in seat, who's actually doing the job and has picked up all of the skills necessary, and only then can the researcher move back.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A practitioner-ready rule for timing the transition: move people back only when a capable operational replacement exists.

quotes.topic_title: Hand-off from research to product teams
quotes.text: As well, it's critical that the team who is taking over from the R&D shop feels like they have control over their own future. You can't really delegate roadmap to an R&D team.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning against letting R&D retain roadmap control once a product team is responsible for outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Hand-off from research to product teams
quotes.text: Last I would say here is really that engineering fundamentals in a lot of ways are the contracts that differentiate an R&D team from an operational product team.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: “engineering fundamentals” as the boundary/contract that enables scaling from research to operations.

quotes.topic_title: Hand-off from research to product teams
quotes.text: Making sure that you've got a good mix of engineers who are comfortable maintaining a service, as well as engineers and researchers who are really thinking about, what is the idea that we've created, what is the new thing that we've brought to market, and can bring that vision to it.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Actionable team design guidance for scaling: balance operational maintainers with vision/idea carriers.

quotes.topic_title: Ethics, safety, and responsible AI filtering
quotes.text: But it brings with it not only engineering challenges, but also, frankly, ethical challenges and legal challenges, like making sense of what our expectations are of AI. If AI produces something that is offensive, who's at fault?
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Highlights that AI product work must explicitly define expectations and accountability, not just solve technical problems.

quotes.topic_title: Ethics, safety, and responsible AI filtering
quotes.text: Our stance on it, what we ended up coming to is actually the framing of Copilot as an AI pair programmer I think is a useful one.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model (“AI pair programmer”) to guide what “acceptable behavior” should look like in-product.

quotes.topic_title: Ethics, safety, and responsible AI filtering
quotes.text: Really coming down to some principles about what is the use case we're trying to solve, what is appropriate, I put this in scare quotes, behavior of the AI bot sitting side by side with you, helped us create some principles or some guidelines for the developer experience that we wanted to create.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Shows a method for responsible AI: derive safety/behavior guidelines from the intended use case and user experience principles.

quotes.topic_title: Ethics, safety, and responsible AI filtering
quotes.text: We introduced a simple block list of words, and these block lists are always fraught with peril, like which words are okay, which words are not okay. All of a sudden, we become editors of language and that's kind of a scary place to be.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A concrete example of early-stage safety controls and the hidden product risk of turning teams into “language editors.”

quotes.topic_title: Ethics, safety, and responsible AI filtering
quotes.text: Being able to start to shift a little bit to focus or to rely on AI models that can also do a better job than we could with crude or simple block lists is maybe another proof point both of how AI as a solution for common development problems is getting way better at solving more parts of our stack or filling in for more parts of our stack.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: Recommends evolving from brittle blocklists to contextual safety models that can interpret intent and sentiment.

quotes.topic_title: Future of AI in the developer workflow
quotes.text: Just to put a fine point on that stat, it is 40% is specifically for Python developers. Candidly, it varies depending upon the language. Because as you might imagine, some languages have better representation in the public domain than others. And usually both the volume and the diversity of training data correlates with the quality of suggestions, which is then represented by either the number of lines written or the acceptance rate or any one of a number of other metrics.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A practical way to evaluate AI coding performance: expect variation by language and tie quality to training-data volume/diversity and measurable acceptance metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Future of AI in the developer workflow
quotes.text: First, I think, I hope it's obvious to most developers that AI is going to infuse pretty much our entire development stack in the not so distant future.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A strategic framing that AI impact will extend beyond code completion into end-to-end developer workflow tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Future of AI in the developer workflow
quotes.text: What if AI could summarize all of your changes with your full request and you just have to, as the contributing developer, just review it to make sure it's accurate, send it on its way, and you don't have to put in extra effort for that.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A concrete workflow improvement idea: use AI to draft PR/commit summaries so developers shift from writing explanations to reviewing them for accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: Future of AI in the developer workflow
quotes.text: There are lots and lots of different opportunities for AI to essentially be able to take some of the drudgery out of our work so that we can focus on creative acts.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A memorable principle for adoption: prioritize AI use-cases that remove rote work and free time for higher-leverage creative tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Future of AI in the developer workflow
quotes.text: Copilot kind of forces me to think a little bit more about what are the design patterns I'm trying to create? What is the end user experience or the outcomes that I'm trying to drive with my code, and that I can rely on Copilot to scaffold out a lot of that so that I can focus on more creative work?
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A counterintuitive effect: AI assistance can push developers up the abstraction stack toward design/outcomes while delegating scaffolding to the tool.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling challenges: GPUs, community trust, and skepticism
quotes.text: It turns out that Copilot for both training and operating the models requires some very rare and unique GPUs that there's not a lot of global supply of. Part of it is just like, can we get enough hardware in order to run these things? We've actually earmarked quite a bit of capacity, and we are greedy, greedy, greedy for more capacity globally. As soon as we can produce those chips and get them in data centers, we do it.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A concrete scaling constraint (GPU scarcity) and an operational response (pre-allocating capacity aggressively) that practitioners can anticipate for AI products.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling challenges: GPUs, community trust, and skepticism
quotes.text: Every good product manager should be spending as much of their time as possible with their customers, with their potential customers.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A direct, actionable principle for PMs—especially critical when launching controversial or novel AI capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling challenges: GPUs, community trust, and skepticism
quotes.text: The amount of give and take between developers and us as a product team has really required us to scale up more of the product team than it has the engineering team.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A counterintuitive scaling lesson: for AI products, community dialogue and product work can become the primary bottleneck over engineering.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling challenges: GPUs, community trust, and skepticism
quotes.text: There's a lot of doubt. There's a lot of very healthy skepticism. Actually I mean that genuinely. I want people to be skeptical of Copilot. We owe it to ourselves as a community to be skeptical of any AI.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A memorable stance that reframes skepticism as a feature, not a bug—useful for building trust and setting expectations in AI rollouts.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling challenges: GPUs, community trust, and skepticism
quotes.text: We think that we've done a really good and responsible job of that by making sure that first, we are very clear that Copilot is not a replacement for a developer. It will never be.
quotes.speaker: Ryan J. Salva
quotes.context: A crisp positioning framework—AI as augmentation rather than replacement—that helps guide product messaging, safety posture, and adoption.
